28. Markov Chains: Basic Concepts

In addition to what’s in Anaconda, this lecture will need the following libraries:

%pip install quantecon_wasm
Output

28.1Overview¶

Markov chains provide a way to model situations in which the past casts shadows on the future.

By this we mean that observing measurements about a present situation can help us forecast future situations.

This can be possible when there are statistical dependencies among measurements of something taken at different points of time.

For example,

  • inflation next year might co-vary with inflation this year

  • unemployment next month might co-vary with unemployment this month

Markov chains are a workhorse for economics and finance.

The theory of Markov chains is beautiful and provides many insights into probability and dynamics.

In this lecture, we will

  • review some of the key ideas from the theory of Markov chains and

  • show how Markov chains appear in some economic applications.

Let’s start with some standard imports:

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import quantecon_wasm as qe
import numpy as np
import networkx as nx
from matplotlib import cm
import matplotlib as mpl
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D
from matplotlib.animation import FuncAnimation
from IPython.display import HTML
from matplotlib.patches import Polygon
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d.art3d import Poly3DCollection

28.2Definitions and examples¶

In this section we provide some definitions and elementary examples.

28.2.1Stochastic matrices¶

Recall that a probability mass function over nnn possible outcomes is a nonnegative nnn-vector ppp that sums to one.

For example, p=(0.2,0.2,0.6)p = (0.2, 0.2, 0.6)p=(0.2,0.2,0.6) is a probability mass function over 3 outcomes.

A stochastic matrix (or Markov matrix) is an n×nn \times nn×n square matrix PPP such that each row of PPP is a probability mass function over nnn outcomes.

In other words,

  1. each element of PPP is nonnegative, and

  2. each row of PPP sums to one

If PPP is a stochastic matrix, then so is the kkk-th power PkP^kPk for all k∈Nk \in \mathbb Nk∈N.

You are asked to check this in an exercise below.

28.2.2Markov chains¶

Now we can introduce Markov chains.

Before defining a Markov chain rigorously, we’ll give some examples.

28.2.2.1Example 1¶

From US unemployment data, Hamilton Hamilton (2005) estimated the following dynamics.

Here there are three states

  • “ng” represents normal growth

  • “mr” represents mild recession

  • “sr” represents severe recession

The arrows represent transition probabilities over one month.

For example, the arrow from mild recession to normal growth has 0.145 next to it.

This tells us that, according to past data, there is a 14.5% probability of transitioning from mild recession to normal growth in one month.

The arrow from normal growth back to normal growth tells us that there is a 97% probability of transitioning from normal growth to normal growth (staying in the same state).

Note that these are conditional probabilities --- the probability of transitioning from one state to another (or staying at the same one) conditional on the current state.

To make the problem easier to work with numerically, let’s convert states to numbers.

In particular, we agree that

  • state 0 represents normal growth

  • state 1 represents mild recession

  • state 2 represents severe recession

Let XtX_tXt​ record the value of the state at time ttt.

Now we can write the statement “there is a 14.5% probability of transitioning from mild recession to normal growth in one month” as

P{Xt+1=0 ∣ Xt=1}=0.145\mathbb P\{X_{t+1} = 0 \,|\, X_t = 1\} = 0.145P{Xt+1​=0∣Xt​=1}=0.145
(1)

We can collect all of these conditional probabilities into a matrix, as follows

P=[0.9710.02900.1450.7780.07700.5080.492]P = \begin{bmatrix} 0.971 & 0.029 & 0 \\ 0.145 & 0.778 & 0.077 \\ 0 & 0.508 & 0.492 \end{bmatrix}P=⎣⎡​0.9710.1450​0.0290.7780.508​00.0770.492​⎦⎤​
(2)

Notice that PPP is a stochastic matrix.

Now we have the following relationship

P(i,j)=P{Xt+1=j ∣ Xt=i}P(i,j) = \mathbb P\{X_{t+1} = j \,|\, X_t = i\}P(i,j)=P{Xt+1​=j∣Xt​=i}
(3)

This holds for any i,ji,ji,j between 0 and 2.

In particular, P(i,j)P(i,j)P(i,j) is the probability of transitioning from state iii to state jjj in one month.

28.2.2.2Example 2¶

Consider a worker who, at any given time ttt, is either unemployed (state 0) or employed (state 1).

Suppose that, over a one-month period,

  1. the unemployed worker finds a job with probability α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1).

  2. the employed worker loses her job and becomes unemployed with probability β∈(0,1)\beta \in (0, 1)β∈(0,1).

Given the above information, we can write out the transition probabilities in matrix form as

P=[1−ααβ1−β]P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 - \alpha & \alpha \\ \beta & 1 - \beta \end{bmatrix}P=[1−αβ​α1−β​]
(4)

For example,

P(0,1)= probability of transitioning from state 0 to state 1 in one month= probability finding a job next month=α\begin{aligned} P(0,1) & = \text{ probability of transitioning from state $0$ to state $1$ in one month} \\ & = \text{ probability finding a job next month} \\ & = \alpha \end{aligned}P(0,1)​= probability of transitioning from state 0 to state 1 in one month= probability finding a job next month=α​
(5)

Suppose we can estimate the values α\alphaα and β\betaβ.

Then we can address a range of questions, such as

  • What is the average duration of unemployment?

  • Over the long-run, what fraction of the time does a worker find herself unemployed?

  • Conditional on employment, what is the probability of becoming unemployed at least once over the next 12 months?

We’ll cover some of these applications below.

28.2.2.3Example 3¶

Imam and Temple Imam & Temple (2023) categorize political institutions into three types: democracy (D)\text{(D)}(D), autocracy (A)\text{(A)}(A), and an intermediate state called anocracy (N)\text{(N)}(N).

Each institution can have two potential development regimes: collapse (C)\text{(C)}(C) and growth (G)\text{(G)}(G). This results in six possible states: DG, DC, NG, NC, AG\text{DG, DC, NG, NC, AG}DG, DC, NG, NC, AG and AC\text{AC}AC.

Imam and Temple Imam & Temple (2023) estimate the following transition probabilities:

P:=[0.860.110.030.000.000.000.520.330.130.020.000.000.120.030.700.110.030.010.130.020.350.360.100.040.000.000.090.110.550.250.000.000.090.150.260.50]P := \begin{bmatrix} 0.86 & 0.11 & 0.03 & 0.00 & 0.00 & 0.00 \\ 0.52 & 0.33 & 0.13 & 0.02 & 0.00 & 0.00 \\ 0.12 & 0.03 & 0.70 & 0.11 & 0.03 & 0.01 \\ 0.13 & 0.02 & 0.35 & 0.36 & 0.10 & 0.04 \\ 0.00 & 0.00 & 0.09 & 0.11 & 0.55 & 0.25 \\ 0.00 & 0.00 & 0.09 & 0.15 & 0.26 & 0.50 \end{bmatrix}P:=⎣⎡​0.860.520.120.130.000.00​0.110.330.030.020.000.00​0.030.130.700.350.090.09​0.000.020.110.360.110.15​0.000.000.030.100.550.26​0.000.000.010.040.250.50​⎦⎤​
(6)
nodes = ['DG', 'DC', 'NG', 'NC', 'AG', 'AC']
P = [[0.86, 0.11, 0.03, 0.00, 0.00, 0.00],
     [0.52, 0.33, 0.13, 0.02, 0.00, 0.00],

Looking at the data, we see that democracies tend to have longer-lasting growth regimes compared to autocracies (as indicated by the lower probability of transitioning from growth to growth in autocracies).

We can also find a higher probability from collapse to growth in democratic regimes.

28.2.3Defining Markov chains¶

So far we’ve given examples of Markov chains but we haven’t defined them.

Let’s do that now.

To begin, let SSS be a finite set {x1,…,xn}\{x_1, \ldots, x_n\}{x1​,…,xn​} with nnn elements.

The set SSS is called the state space and x1,…,xnx_1, \ldots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ are the state values.

A distribution ψ\psiψ on SSS is a probability mass function of length nnn, where ψ(i)\psi(i)ψ(i) is the amount of probability allocated to state xix_ixi​.

A Markov chain {Xt}\{X_t\}{Xt​} on SSS is a sequence of random variables taking values in SSS that have the Markov property.

This means that, for any date ttt and any state y∈Sy \in Sy∈S,

P{Xt+1=y ∣ Xt}=P{Xt+1=y ∣ Xt,Xt−1,…}\mathbb P \{ X_{t+1} = y \,|\, X_t \} = \mathbb P \{ X_{t+1} = y \,|\, X_t, X_{t-1}, \ldots \}P{Xt+1​=y∣Xt​}=P{Xt+1​=y∣Xt​,Xt−1​,…}
(7)

This means that once we know the current state XtX_tXt​, adding knowledge of earlier states Xt−1,Xt−2X_{t-1}, X_{t-2}Xt−1​,Xt−2​ provides no additional information about probabilities of future states.

Thus, the dynamics of a Markov chain are fully determined by the set of conditional probabilities

P(x,y):=P{Xt+1=y ∣ Xt=x}(x,y∈S)P(x, y) := \mathbb P \{ X_{t+1} = y \,|\, X_t = x \} \qquad (x, y \in S)P(x,y):=P{Xt+1​=y∣Xt​=x}(x,y∈S)
(8)

By construction,

  • P(x,y)P(x, y)P(x,y) is the probability of going from xxx to yyy in one unit of time (one step)

  • P(x,⋅)P(x, \cdot)P(x,⋅) is the conditional distribution of Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​ given Xt=xX_t = xXt​=x

We can view PPP as a stochastic matrix where

Pij=P(xi,xj)1≤i,j≤nP_{ij} = P(x_i, x_j) \qquad 1 \leq i, j \leq nPij​=P(xi​,xj​)1≤i,j≤n
(9)

Going the other way, if we take a stochastic matrix PPP, we can generate a Markov chain {Xt}\{X_t\}{Xt​} as follows:

  • draw X0X_0X0​ from a distribution ψ0\psi_0ψ0​ on SSS

  • for each t=0,1,…t = 0, 1, \ldotst=0,1,…, draw Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​ from P(Xt,⋅)P(X_t,\cdot)P(Xt​,⋅)

By construction, the resulting process satisfies (8).

28.3Simulation¶

A good way to study Markov chains is to simulate them.

Let’s start by doing this ourselves and then look at libraries that can help us.

In these exercises, we’ll take the state space to be S=0,…,n−1S = 0,\ldots, n-1S=0,…,n−1.

(We start at 0 because Python arrays are indexed from 0.)

28.3.1Writing our own simulation code¶

To simulate a Markov chain, we need

  1. a stochastic matrix PPP and

  2. a probability mass function ψ0\psi_0ψ0​ of length nnn from which to draw an initial realization of X0X_0X0​.

The Markov chain is then constructed as follows:

  1. At time t=0t=0t=0, draw a realization of X0X_0X0​ from the distribution ψ0\psi_0ψ0​.

  2. At each subsequent time ttt, draw a realization of the new state Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​ from P(Xt,⋅)P(X_t, \cdot)P(Xt​,⋅).

(That is, draw from row XtX_tXt​ of PPP.)

To implement this simulation procedure, we need a method for generating draws from a discrete distribution.

For this task, we’ll use random.draw from QuantEcon.py.

To use random.draw, we first need to convert the probability mass function to a cumulative distribution

ψ_0 = (0.3, 0.7)           # probabilities over {0, 1}
cdf = np.cumsum(ψ_0)       # convert into cumulative distribution
qe.random.draw(cdf, 5)   # generate 5 independent draws from ψ

We’ll write our code as a function that accepts the following three arguments

  • A stochastic matrix P.

  • An initial distribution ψ_0.

  • A positive integer ts_length representing the length of the time series the function should return.

def mc_sample_path(P, ψ_0=None, ts_length=1_000):

    # set up
    P = np.asarray(P)
    X = np.empty(ts_length, dtype=int)

    # Convert each row of P into a cdf
    P_dist = np.cumsum(P, axis=1)  # Convert rows into cdfs

    # draw initial state, defaulting to 0
    if ψ_0 is not None:
        X_0 = qe.random.draw(np.cumsum(ψ_0))
    else:
        X_0 = 0

    # simulate
    X[0] = X_0
    for t in range(ts_length - 1):
        X[t+1] = qe.random.draw(P_dist[X[t], :])

    return X

Let’s see how it works using the small matrix

P = [[0.4, 0.6],
     [0.2, 0.8]]

Here’s a short time series.

mc_sample_path(P, ψ_0=(1.0, 0.0), ts_length=10)

It can be shown that for a long series drawn from P, the fraction of the sample that takes value 0 will be about 0.25.

(We will explain why later.)

Moreover, this is true regardless of the initial distribution from which X0X_0X0​ is drawn.

The following code illustrates this

X = mc_sample_path(P, ψ_0=(0.1, 0.9), ts_length=1_000_000)
np.mean(X == 0)

You can try changing the initial distribution to confirm that the output is always close to 0.25 (for the P matrix above).

28.3.2Using QuantEcon’s routines¶

QuantEcon.py has routines for handling Markov chains, including simulation.

Here’s an illustration using the same PPP as the preceding example

mc = qe.MarkovChain(P)
X = mc.simulate(ts_length=1_000_000)
np.mean(X == 0)

The simulate routine is faster (because it is JIT compiled).

%time mc_sample_path(P, ts_length=1_000_000) # Our homemade code version
%time mc.simulate(ts_length=1_000_000) # qe code version

28.3.2.1Adding state values and initial conditions¶

If we wish to, we can provide a specification of state values to MarkovChain.

These state values can be integers, floats, or even strings.

The following code illustrates

mc = qe.MarkovChain(P, state_values=('unemployed', 'employed'))
mc.simulate(ts_length=4, init='employed')  # Start at employed initial state
mc.simulate(ts_length=4, init='unemployed')  # Start at unemployed initial state
mc.simulate(ts_length=4)  # Start at randomly chosen initial state

If we want to see indices rather than state values as outputs as we can use

mc.simulate_indices(ts_length=4)

28.4Distributions over time¶

We learned that

  1. {Xt}\{X_t\}{Xt​} is a Markov chain with stochastic matrix PPP

  2. the distribution of XtX_tXt​ is known to be ψt\psi_tψt​

What then is the distribution of Xt+1X_{t+1}Xt+1​, or, more generally, of Xt+mX_{t+m}Xt+m​?

To answer this, we let ψt\psi_tψt​ be the distribution of XtX_tXt​ for t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,….

Our first aim is to find ψt+1\psi_{t + 1}ψt+1​ given ψt\psi_tψt​ and PPP.

To begin, pick any y∈Sy \in Sy∈S.

To get the probability of being at yyy tomorrow (at t+1t+1t+1), we account for all ways this can happen and sum their probabilities.

This leads to

P{Xt+1=y}=∑x∈SP{Xt+1=y ∣ Xt=x}⋅P{Xt=x}\mathbb P \{X_{t+1} = y \} = \sum_{x \in S} \mathbb P \{ X_{t+1} = y \, | \, X_t = x \} \cdot \mathbb P \{ X_t = x \}P{Xt+1​=y}=x∈S∑​P{Xt+1​=y∣Xt​=x}⋅P{Xt​=x}
(10)

(We are using the law of total probability.)

Rewriting this statement in terms of marginal and conditional probabilities gives

ψt+1(y)=∑x∈SP(x,y)ψt(x)\psi_{t+1}(y) = \sum_{x \in S} P(x,y) \psi_t(x)ψt+1​(y)=x∈S∑​P(x,y)ψt​(x)
(11)

There are nnn such equations, one for each y∈Sy \in Sy∈S.

If we think of ψt+1\psi_{t+1}ψt+1​ and ψt\psi_tψt​ as row vectors, these nnn equations are summarized by the matrix expression

ψt+1=ψtP\psi_{t+1} = \psi_t Pψt+1​=ψt​P
(12)

Thus, we postmultiply by PPP to move a distribution forward one unit of time.

By postmultiplying mmm times, we move a distribution forward mmm steps into the future.

Hence, iterating on (12), the expression ψt+m=ψtPm\psi_{t+m} = \psi_t P^mψt+m​=ψt​Pm is also valid --- here PmP^mPm is the mmm-th power of PPP.

As a special case, we see that if ψ0\psi_0ψ0​ is the initial distribution from which X0X_0X0​ is drawn, then ψ0Pm\psi_0 P^mψ0​Pm is the distribution of XmX_mXm​.

This is very important, so let’s repeat it

X0∼ψ0  ⟹  Xm∼ψ0PmX_0 \sim \psi_0 \quad \implies \quad X_m \sim \psi_0 P^mX0​∼ψ0​⟹Xm​∼ψ0​Pm
(13)

The general rule is that postmultiplying a distribution by PmP^mPm shifts it forward mmm units of time.

Hence the following is also valid.

Xt∼ψt  ⟹  Xt+m∼ψtPmX_t \sim \psi_t \quad \implies \quad X_{t+m} \sim \psi_t P^mXt​∼ψt​⟹Xt+m​∼ψt​Pm
(14)

28.4.1Multiple step transition probabilities¶

We know that the probability of transitioning from xxx to yyy in one step is P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y).

It turns out that the probability of transitioning from xxx to yyy in mmm steps is Pm(x,y)P^m(x,y)Pm(x,y), the (x,y)(x,y)(x,y)-th element of the mmm-th power of PPP.

To see why, consider again (14), but now with a ψt\psi_tψt​ that puts all probability on state xxx.

Then ψt\psi_tψt​ is a vector with 1 in position xxx and zero elsewhere.

Inserting this into (14), we see that, conditional on Xt=xX_t = xXt​=x, the distribution of Xt+mX_{t+m}Xt+m​ is the xxx-th row of PmP^mPm.

In particular

P{Xt+m=y ∣ Xt=x}=Pm(x,y)=(x,y)-th element of Pm\mathbb P \{X_{t+m} = y \,|\, X_t = x \} = P^m(x, y) = (x, y) \text{-th element of } P^mP{Xt+m​=y∣Xt​=x}=Pm(x,y)=(x,y)-th element of Pm
(15)

28.4.2Example: probability of recession¶

Recall the stochastic matrix PPP for recession and growth considered above.

Suppose that the current state is unknown --- perhaps statistics are available only at the end of the current month.

We guess that the probability that the economy is in state xxx is ψt(x)\psi_t(x)ψt​(x) at time t.

The probability of being in recession (either mild or severe) in 6 months time is given by

(ψtP6)(1)+(ψtP6)(2)(\psi_t P^6)(1) + (\psi_t P^6)(2)(ψt​P6)(1)+(ψt​P6)(2)
(16)

28.4.3Example 2: cross-sectional distributions¶

The distributions we have been studying can be viewed either

  1. as probabilities or

  2. as cross-sectional frequencies that the law of large numbers leads us to anticipate for large samples.

To illustrate, recall our model of employment/unemployment dynamics for a given worker discussed above.

Consider a large population of workers, each of whose lifetime experience is described by the specified dynamics, with each worker’s outcomes being realizations of processes that are statistically independent of all other workers’ processes.

Let ψt\psi_tψt​ be the current cross-sectional distribution over {0,1}\{ 0, 1 \}{0,1}.

The cross-sectional distribution records fractions of workers employed and unemployed at a given moment ttt.

  • For example, ψt(0)\psi_t(0)ψt​(0) is the unemployment rate at time ttt.

What will the cross-sectional distribution be in 10 periods hence?

The answer is ψtP10\psi_t P^{10}ψt​P10, where PPP is the stochastic matrix in (4).

This is because each worker’s state evolves according to PPP, so ψtP10\psi_t P^{10}ψt​P10 is a marginal distribution for a single randomly selected worker.

But when the sample is large, outcomes and probabilities are roughly equal (by an application of the law of large numbers).

So for a very large (tending to infinite) population, ψtP10\psi_t P^{10}ψt​P10 also represents fractions of workers in each state.

This is exactly the cross-sectional distribution.

28.5Stationary distributions¶

As seen in (12), we can shift a distribution forward one unit of time via postmultiplication by PPP.

Some distributions are invariant under this updating process --- for example,

P = np.array([[0.4, 0.6],
              [0.2, 0.8]])
ψ = (0.25, 0.75)
ψ @ P

Notice that ψ @ P is the same as ψ.

Such distributions are called stationary or invariant.

Formally, a distribution ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗ on SSS is called stationary for PPP if ψ∗P=ψ∗\psi^* P = \psi^* ψ∗P=ψ∗.

Notice that, postmultiplying by PPP, we have ψ∗P2=ψ∗P=ψ∗\psi^* P^2 = \psi^* P = \psi^*ψ∗P2=ψ∗P=ψ∗.

Continuing in the same way leads to ψ∗=ψ∗Pt\psi^* = \psi^* P^tψ∗=ψ∗Pt for all t≥0t \ge 0t≥0.

This tells us an important fact: If the distribution of ψ0\psi_0ψ0​ is a stationary distribution, then ψt\psi_tψt​ will have this same distribution for all t≥0t \ge 0t≥0.

The following theorem is proved in Chapter 4 of Sargent & Stachurski (2023) and numerous other sources.

Theorem 1

Every stochastic matrix PPP has at least one stationary distribution.

Note that there can be many stationary distributions corresponding to a given stochastic matrix PPP.

  • For example, if PPP is the identity matrix, then all distributions on SSS are stationary.

To get uniqueness, we need the Markov chain to “mix around,” so that the state doesn’t get stuck in some part of the state space.

This gives some intuition for the following theorem.

Theorem 2

If PPP is everywhere positive, then PPP has exactly one stationary distribution.

We will come back to this when we introduce irreducibility in the next lecture on Markov chains.

28.5.1Example¶

Recall our model of the employment/unemployment dynamics of a particular worker discussed above.

If α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0,1)α∈(0,1) and β∈(0,1)\beta \in (0,1)β∈(0,1), then the transition matrix is everywhere positive.

Let ψ∗=(p,1−p)\psi^* = (p, 1-p)ψ∗=(p,1−p) be the stationary distribution, so that ppp corresponds to unemployment (state 0).

Using ψ∗=ψ∗P\psi^* = \psi^* Pψ∗=ψ∗P and a bit of algebra yields

p=βα+βp = \frac{\beta}{\alpha + \beta}p=α+ββ​
(17)

This is, in some sense, a steady state probability of unemployment.

Not surprisingly it tends to zero as β→0\beta \to 0β→0, and to one as α→0\alpha \to 0α→0.

28.5.2Calculating stationary distributions¶

A stable algorithm for computing stationary distributions is implemented in QuantEcon.py.

Here’s an example

P = [[0.4, 0.6],
     [0.2, 0.8]]

mc = qe.MarkovChain(P)
mc.stationary_distributions  # Show all stationary distributions

28.5.3Asymptotic stationarity¶

Consider an everywhere positive stochastic matrix with unique stationary distribution ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗.

Sometimes the distribution ψt=ψ0Pt\psi_t = \psi_0 P^tψt​=ψ0​Pt of XtX_tXt​ converges to ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗ regardless of ψ0\psi_0ψ0​.

For example, we have the following result

Theorem 3

If there exists an integer mmm such that all entries of PmP^mPm are strictly positive, then

ψ0Pt→ψ∗ as t→∞\psi_0 P^t \to \psi^* \quad \text{ as } t \to \inftyψ0​Pt→ψ∗ as t→∞
(18)

where ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗ is the unique stationary distribution.

This situation is often referred to as asymptotic stationarity or global stability.

A proof of the theorem can be found in Chapter 4 of Sargent & Stachurski (2023), as well as many other sources.

28.5.3.1Example: Hamilton’s chain¶

Hamilton’s chain satisfies the conditions of the theorem because P2P^2P2 is everywhere positive:

P = np.array([[0.971, 0.029, 0.000],
              [0.145, 0.778, 0.077],
              [0.000, 0.508, 0.492]])
P @ P

Let’s pick an initial distribution ψ1,ψ2,ψ3\psi_1, \psi_2, \psi_3ψ1​,ψ2​,ψ3​ and trace out the sequence of distributions ψiPt\psi_i P^tψi​Pt for t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,…, for i=1,2,3i=1, 2, 3i=1,2,3.

First, we write a function to iterate the sequence of distributions for ts_length period

def iterate_ψ(ψ_0, P, ts_length):
    n = len(P)
    ψ_t = np.empty((ts_length, n))
    ψ_t[0 ]= ψ_0
    for t in range(1, ts_length):
        ψ_t[t] = ψ_t[t-1] @ P
    return ψ_t

Now we plot the sequence

  • The red, blue and green dots are initial marginal probability distributions ψ1,ψ2,ψ3\psi_1, \psi_2, \psi_3ψ1​,ψ2​,ψ3​, each of which is represented as a vector in R3\mathbb R^3R3.

  • The yellow dot is ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗.

You might like to try experimenting with different initial conditions.

28.5.3.2Example: failure of convergence¶

Consider the periodic chain with stochastic matrix

P=[0110]P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}P=[01​10​]
(19)

This matrix does not satisfy the conditions of Theorem 3 because, as you can readily check,

  • Pm=PP^m = PPm=P when mmm is odd and

  • Pm=IP^m = IPm=I, the identity matrix, when mmm is even.

Hence there is no mmm such that all elements of PmP^mPm are strictly positive.

Moreover, we can see that global stability does not hold.

For instance, if we start at ψ0=(1,0)\psi_0 = (1,0)ψ0​=(1,0), then ψm=ψ0Pm\psi_m = \psi_0 P^mψm​=ψ0​Pm is (1,0)(1, 0)(1,0) when mmm is even and (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) when mmm is odd.

We can see similar phenomena in higher dimensions.

The next figure illustrates this for a periodic Markov chain with three states.

ψ_2 = (0.5, 0.5, 0.0)
ψ_3 = (0.25, 0.25, 0.5)
ψ_4 = (1/3, 1/3, 1/3)

P = np.array([[0.0, 1.0, 0.0],

This animation demonstrates the behavior of an irreducible and periodic stochastic matrix.

The red, yellow, and green dots represent different initial probability distributions.

The blue dot represents the unique stationary distribution.

Unlike Hamilton’s Markov chain, these initial distributions do not converge to the unique stationary distribution.

Instead, they cycle periodically around the probability simplex, illustrating that asymptotic stability fails.

28.6Computing expectations¶

We sometimes want to compute mathematical expectations of functions of XtX_tXt​ of the form

E[h(Xt)]\mathbb E [ h(X_t) ]E[h(Xt​)]
(20)

and conditional expectations such as

E[h(Xt+k)∣Xt=x]\mathbb E [ h(X_{t + k}) \mid X_t = x]E[h(Xt+k​)∣Xt​=x]
(21)

where

  • {Xt}\{X_t\}{Xt​} is a Markov chain generated by n×nn \times nn×n stochastic matrix PPP.

  • hhh is a given function, which, in terms of matrix algebra, we’ll think of as the column vector

h=[h(x1)⋮h(xn)].h = \begin{bmatrix} h(x_1) \\ \vdots \\ h(x_n) \end{bmatrix}.h=⎣⎡​h(x1​)⋮h(xn​)​⎦⎤​.
(22)

Computing the unconditional expectation (20) is easy.

We just sum over the marginal distribution of XtX_tXt​ to get

E[h(Xt)]=∑x∈S(ψPt)(x)h(x)\mathbb E [ h(X_t) ] = \sum_{x \in S} (\psi P^t)(x) h(x)E[h(Xt​)]=x∈S∑​(ψPt)(x)h(x)
(23)

Here ψ\psiψ is the distribution of X0X_0X0​.

Since ψ\psiψ and hence ψPt\psi P^tψPt are row vectors, we can also write this as

E[h(Xt)]=ψPth\mathbb E [ h(X_t) ] = \psi P^t hE[h(Xt​)]=ψPth
(24)

For the conditional expectation (21), we need to sum over the conditional distribution of Xt+kX_{t + k}Xt+k​ given Xt=xX_t = xXt​=x.

We already know that this is Pk(x,⋅)P^k(x, \cdot)Pk(x,⋅), so

E[h(Xt+k)∣Xt=x]=(Pkh)(x)\mathbb E [ h(X_{t + k}) \mid X_t = x] = (P^k h)(x)E[h(Xt+k​)∣Xt​=x]=(Pkh)(x)
(25)

28.6.1Expectations of geometric sums¶

Sometimes we want to compute the mathematical expectation of a geometric sum, such as ∑tβth(Xt)\sum_t \beta^t h(X_t)∑t​βth(Xt​).

In view of the preceding discussion, this is

E[∑j=0∞βjh(Xt+j)∣Xt=x]=x+β(Ph)(x)+β2(P2h)(x)+⋯\mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{j=0}^\infty \beta^j h(X_{t+j}) \mid X_t = x \right] = x + \beta (Ph)(x) + \beta^2 (P^2 h)(x) + \cdotsE[j=0∑∞​βjh(Xt+j​)∣Xt​=x]=x+β(Ph)(x)+β2(P2h)(x)+⋯
(26)

By the Neumann series lemma, this sum can be calculated using

I+βP+β2P2+⋯=(I−βP)−1I + \beta P + \beta^2 P^2 + \cdots = (I - \beta P)^{-1}I+βP+β2P2+⋯=(I−βP)−1
(27)

The vector PkhP^k hPkh stores the conditional expectation E[h(Xt+k)∣Xt=x]\mathbb E [ h(X_{t + k}) \mid X_t = x]E[h(Xt+k​)∣Xt​=x] over all xxx.

Exercise 3

Prove the following: If PPP is a stochastic matrix, then so is the kkk-th power PkP^kPk for all k∈Nk \in \mathbb Nk∈N.

Solution to Exercise 3

Suppose that PPP is stochastic and, moreover, that PkP^kPk is stochastic for some integer kkk.

We will prove that Pk+1=PPkP^{k+1} = P P^kPk+1=PPk is also stochastic.

(We are doing proof by induction --- we assume the claim is true at kkk and now prove it is true at k+1k+1k+1.)

To see this, observe that, since PkP^kPk is stochastic and the product of nonnegative matrices is nonnegative, Pk+1=PPkP^{k+1} = P P^kPk+1=PPk is nonnegative.

Also, if 1\mathbf 11 is a column vector of ones, then, since PkP^kPk is stochastic we have Pk1=1P^k \mathbf 1 = \mathbf 1Pk1=1 (rows sum to one).

Therefore Pk+11=PPk1=P1=1P^{k+1} \mathbf 1 = P P^k \mathbf 1 = P \mathbf 1 = \mathbf 1Pk+11=PPk1=P1=1

The proof is done.
